elements.content: The facile self-assembly reactions of 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane-7-oxide (PTAO) with AgNO3 or Ag2SO4 give rise to the generation of two new distinct silver–organic frameworks [Ag(NO3)(μ3-PTAO)] n (1) and [Ag2(μ2-SO4)(μ5-PTAO)(H2O)] n (2), respectively. They have been characterized by IR, 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopies, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS)(±), and elemental and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, the latter featuring infinite three-dimensional (3D) non-interpenetrating networks driven by multiply bridging PTAO spacers that adopt undocumented N2O- or N3O-coordination modes. The topological analysis of 1 reveals a uninodal 3-connected net with the point (Schläfli) symbol of (103) and the srs topological type, whereas 2 shows a rare trinodal 3,4,5-connected net with the unprecedented topology defined by the point symbol of (5.6.7)(54.6.8)(54.63.83). Compounds 1 and 2 represent the first 3D metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) derived from PTAO or any cage-like PTA derivative, thus opening up their underexplored applications as versatile building blocks in crystal engineering. Furthermore, 1 and 2 exhibit significant antibacterial and antifungal activities studied in vitro against Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, and Candida albicans.
elements.clean_text: The facile self-assembly reactions of 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane-7-oxide (PTAO) with AgNO3 or Ag2SO4 give rise to the generation of two new distinct silver-organic frameworks [Ag(NO3)(μ3-PTAO)] n  (1) and [Ag2(μ2-SO4)(μ5-PTAO)(H2O)] n  (2), respectively. They have been characterized by IR, 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopies, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS)(±), and elemental and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, the latter featuring infinite three-dimensional (3D) non-interpenetrating networks driven by multiply bridging PTAO spacers that adopt undocumented N2O- or N3O-coordination modes. The topological analysis of 1 reveals a uninodal 3-connected net with the point (Schläfli) symbol of (103) and the srs topological type, whereas 2 shows a rare trinodal 3,4,5-connected net with the unprecedented topology defined by the point symbol of (5.6.7)(54.6.8)(54.63.83). Compounds 1 and 2 represent the first 3D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) derived from PTAO or any cage-like PTA derivative, thus opening up their underexplored applications as versatile building blocks in crystal engineering. Furthermore, 1 and 2 exhibit significant antibacterial and antifungal activities studied in vitro against Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, and Candida albicans.

elements.content: Two novel silver−organic three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with distinct topologies have been self-assembled from silver(I) salts and PTAO, thus opening up its use as a new versatile N,O-building block in crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text: Two novel silver-organic three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with distinct topologies have been self-assembled from silver(I) salts and PTAO, thus opening up its use as a new versatile N,O-building block in crystal engineering.

elements.content: The design of new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers is nowadays a very popular research topic in the areas of crystal engineering, coordination and materials chemistry, as attested by the rapidly growing number of research publications in the field, including state-of-the-art books and reviews. Although a great variety of organic bridging ligands (typically N- or O-donors such as diamines, polypyridine, or polycarboxylate derivatives) have been used as building blocks for the construction of MOFs, the search for new versatile multidentate spacers capable of adopting different coordination modes and their application in crystal engineering to generate novel types of framework materials are of high current interest.
elements.clean_text: The design of new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers is nowadays a very popular research topic in the areas of crystal engineering, coordination and materials chemistry, as attested by the rapidly growing number of research publications in the field, including state-of-the-art books and reviews. Although a great variety of organic bridging ligands (typically N- or O-donors such as diamines, polypyridine, or polycarboxylate derivatives) have been used as building blocks for the construction of MOFs, the search for new versatile multidentate spacers capable of adopting different coordination modes and their application in crystal engineering to generate novel types of framework materials are of high current interest.

elements.content: In particular, the water-soluble aminophosphine 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA, Scheme ) and its various cage-like derivatives are very important ligands in aqueous organometallic chemistry, which, due to the presence of up to four coordinating sites and the diamondoid geometry, can also become rather versatile building blocks for the construction of metal–organic networks. Although a number of PTA-driven one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) coordination polymers have emerged in recent years, the three-dimensional (3D) MOFs bearing PTA or any of its cagelike derivatives remain virtually unknown. Hence, the filling of this gap constitutes a main objective of the current work.
elements.clean_text: In particular, the water-soluble aminophosphine 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA, Scheme ) and its various cage-like derivatives are very important ligands in aqueous organometallic chemistry, which, due to the presence of up to four coordinating sites and the diamondoid geometry, can also become rather versatile building blocks for the construction of metal-organic networks. Although a number of PTA-driven one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) coordination polymers have emerged in recent years, the three-dimensional (3D) MOFs bearing PTA or any of its cagelike derivatives remain virtually unknown. Hence, the filling of this gap constitutes a main objective of the current work.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-00571y_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Following our general research projects on the design of new metal–organic networks and on the coordination chemistry of PTA and derived ligands, we have recently reported (i) a new series of Ag(I) coordination polymers obtained via a unique synthetic entry allowing the controlled N,P-coordination mode of PTA and (ii) the first metal complex bearing 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane-7-oxide (PTAO, Scheme ). As an extension of these studies, the present work also aims at opening up the application of PTAO as a new and still unexplored N,O-building block for the engineering of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Following our general research projects on the design of new metal-organic networks and on the coordination chemistry of PTA and derived ligands, we have recently reported (i) a new series of Ag(I) coordination polymers obtained via a unique synthetic entry allowing the controlled N,P-coordination mode of PTA and (ii) the first metal complex bearing 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane-7-oxide (PTAO, Scheme ). As an extension of these studies, the present work also aims at opening up the application of PTAO as a new and still unexplored N,O-building block for the engineering of MOFs.

elements.content: Hence, we report herein the facile self-assembly synthesis and characterization of two distinct 3D silver–organic frameworks, [Ag(NO3)(μ3-PTA=O)] n (1) and [Ag2(μ2-SO4)(μ5-PTAO)(H2O)] n (2), which constitute the first 3D MOFs derived from any cagelike PTA derivative. Besides, apart from representing the first Ag-PTAO compounds (only rare examples of PTA oxide complexes are known), 1 and 2 also feature the undocumented N2,O- and N3,O-coordination modes of PTAO.
elements.clean_text: Hence, we report herein the facile self-assembly synthesis and characterization of two distinct 3D silver-organic frameworks, [Ag(NO3)(μ3-PTA=O)] n  (1) and [Ag2(μ2-SO4)(μ5-PTAO)(H2O)] n  (2), which constitute the first 3D MOFs derived from any cagelike PTA derivative. Besides, apart from representing the first Ag-PTAO compounds (only rare examples of PTA oxide complexes are known), 1 and 2 also feature the undocumented N2,O- and N3,O-coordination modes of PTAO.

elements.content: The reaction of silver(I) nitrate with PTAO as the main ligand and spacer, in equimolar amounts at 20 °C in MeOH/CH2Cl2 medium, followed by the alkalization with NH4OH, leads to the self-assembly formation of the polymer 1, in which PTAO acts as a μ3-spacer (Scheme ). However, a resembling synthetic procedure with silver(I) sulfate as the metal source and in MeCN/H2O medium (different solvent composition was used to facilitate crystallization) results in the generation of the distinct and more complex polymer 2, wherein the coordination network is driven by neutral μ5-PTAO spacers and μ2-SO4 linkers. These MOFs have been isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on Ag salt). As expected for PTA derivatives, compounds 1 and 2 are moderately soluble in water, showing the S 25°C values of 2.0 and 5.0 mg mL–1, respectively. Their molecular structures have been established by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, and supported by elemental analysis, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS)(±), IR and NMR spectroscopies.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of silver(I) nitrate with PTAO as the main ligand and spacer, in equimolar amounts at 20 °C in MeOH/CH2Cl2 medium, followed by the alkalization with NH4OH, leads to the self-assembly formation of the polymer 1, in which PTAO acts as a μ3-spacer (Scheme ). However, a resembling synthetic procedure with silver(I) sulfate as the metal source and in MeCN/H2O medium (different solvent composition was used to facilitate crystallization) results in the generation of the distinct and more complex polymer 2, wherein the coordination network is driven by neutral μ5-PTAO spacers and μ2-SO4 linkers. These MOFs have been isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on Ag salt). As expected for PTA derivatives, compounds 1 and 2 are moderately soluble in water, showing the S 25°C values of 2.0 and 5.0 mg mL-1, respectively. Their molecular structures have been established by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, and supported by elemental analysis, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS)(±), IR and NMR spectroscopies.

elements.content:
Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulae of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> <xref rid="sch2-fn1"></xref>

Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.
elements.clean_text: 2  Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulae of 1 and 2       a Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.

elements.content: Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.
elements.clean_text: a Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1 and 2 exhibit related features with vibrations in the 2970–2870 and 1440–400 cm–1 ranges due to the PTAO cores, showing in particular the characteristic intense ν(PO) bands with maxima at 1165 (1) and 1144 (2) cm–1. In addition, ν(NO3) or ν(SO4) bands are detected at 1384 and 1138 cm–1, respectively. The ESI-MS(+) plots of aqueous solutions of both compounds show the [Ag(PTAO)2]+ (m/z = 454), [Ag(PTAO)(H2O)2]+ (m/z = 319), [Ag(PTAO)]+ (m/z = 281), and [PTAO + H]+ (m/z = 174) fragments with expected isotopic distribution patterns, whereas the ESI-MS(−) spectra feature the characteristic [Ag(NO3)2]− (m/z = 232) or [Ag(SO4)]− (m/z = 204) fragments. The 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra also reveal the expected resonances at typical chemical shifts for the PTAO moieties.
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of 1 and 2 exhibit related features with vibrations in the 2970-2870 and 1440-400 cm-1 ranges due to the PTAO cores, showing in particular the characteristic intense ν(PO) bands with maxima at 1165 (1) and 1144 (2) cm-1. In addition, ν(NO3) or ν(SO4) bands are detected at 1384 and 1138 cm-1, respectively. The ESI-MS(+) plots of aqueous solutions of both compounds show the [Ag(PTAO)2]+ (m/z = 454), [Ag(PTAO)(H2O)2]+ (m/z = 319), [Ag(PTAO)]+ (m/z = 281), and [PTAO + H]+ (m/z = 174) fragments with expected isotopic distribution patterns, whereas the ESI-MS(-) spectra feature the characteristic [Ag(NO3)2]- (m/z = 232) or [Ag(SO4)]- (m/z = 204) fragments. The 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra also reveal the expected resonances at typical chemical shifts for the PTAO moieties.

elements.content: The orthorhombic structure of 1 (Figure ) crystallizes within the chiral P212121 space group and is composed of the Ag1 atom, one μ3-PTAO moiety, and one nitrate ligand per formula unit. The coordination environment of each five-coordinate Ag1 atom is occupied by three alternately N- and O-bound μ3-PTAO ligands [Ag1–N11 2.341(2), Ag1–N13i 2.309(2), Ag1–O1 2.414(2) Å] and one η2-NO3 – ligand [Ag1–O11 2.562(3), Ag1–O12 2.739(2) Å] (Figure a), forming a significantly distorted {AgO3N2} square-pyramidal secondary building unit (SBU), wherein the axial site is occupied by the O1 atom. These units are bridged by μ3-PTAO spacers generating three kinds of the Ag1-PTAO–Ag1-PTAO helical chain motifs () running along the a, b, and c axis if one considers the connections of the adjacent Ag1 atoms via the N13/O1, N11/N13, and N11/O1 donor pairs of PTAO, respectively. These helical motifs have the respective pitches of 7.7286(4), 10.0328(6), and 13.4998(8) Å (equal to the a, b, and c unit cell dimensions) and multiply interweave through a third donor atom of PTAO into an infinite 3D noninterpenetrating helical framework (Figures b and ). Interestingly, if seen along the a axis (Figure b), this network resembles a “basket weave” topology composed of long and short stitches.

The coordination environment of each five-coordinate Ag1 atom is occupied by three alternately N- and O-bound μ3-PTAO ligands [Ag1-N11 2.341(2), Ag1-N13i 2.309(2), Ag1-O1 2.414(2) Å] and one η2-NO3 - ligand [Ag1-O11 2.562(3), Ag1-O12 2.739(2) Å] (Figure a), forming a significantly distorted {AgO3N2} square-pyramidal secondary building unit (SBU), wherein the axial site is occupied by the O1 atom. These units are bridged by μ3-PTAO spacers generating three kinds of the Ag1-PTAO-Ag1-PTAO helical chain motifs () running along the a, b, and c axis if one considers the connections of the adjacent Ag1 atoms via the N13/O1, N11/N13, and N11/O1 donor pairs of PTAO, respectively. These helical motifs have the respective pitches of 7.7286(4), 10.0328(6), and 13.4998(8) Å (equal to the a, b, and c unit cell dimensions) and multiply interweave through a third donor atom of PTAO into an infinite 3D noninterpenetrating helical framework (Figures b and ). Interestingly, if seen along the a axis (Figure b), this network resembles a "basket weave" topology composed of long and short stitches.

elements.content: Structural fragments of 1 showing: (a) ellipsoid plot with partial labeling scheme, (b) helical 3D framework, and (c) topological representation of the simplified underlying 3-connected net with the point symbol of (103). Further details: (a) 50% probability ellipsoids, H atoms are omitted for clarity; (b) rotated view along the a axis, H atoms and nitrate ligands are omitted for clarity, color codes: Ag balls (magenta), N (blue), P (orange), O (red), C (cyan); (c) rotated view along the c axis, topologically equivalent 3-connected Ag1 nodes and centroids of PTAO nodes are shown as magenta and cyan sticks, respectively. Selected distances (Å): Ag1–N11 2.341(2), Ag1–N13i 2.309(2), Ag1–O1 2.414(2), Ag1–O11 2.562(3), Ag1–O12 2.739(2), P1–O1 1.490(2), Ag1···Ag1iii 5.939(1), Ag1ii···Ag1iii 6.918(1), Ag1···Ag1ii 8.298(1). Symmetry operators: (i) −0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, 2 – z, (ii) 0.5 – x, 1 – y, −0.5 + z, (iii) –x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 – z.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structural fragments of 1 showing: (a) ellipsoid plot with partial labeling scheme, (b) helical 3D framework, and (c) topological representation of the simplified underlying 3-connected net with the point symbol of (103). Further details: (a) 50% probability ellipsoids, H atoms are omitted for clarity; (b) rotated view along the a axis, H atoms and nitrate ligands are omitted for clarity, color codes: Ag balls (magenta), N (blue), P (orange), O (red), C (cyan); (c) rotated view along the c axis, topologically equivalent 3-connected Ag1 nodes and centroids of PTAO nodes are shown as magenta and cyan sticks, respectively. Selected distances (Å): Ag1-N11 2.341(2), Ag1-N13i 2.309(2), Ag1-O1 2.414(2), Ag1-O11 2.562(3), Ag1-O12 2.739(2), P1-O1 1.490(2), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1iii 5.939(1), Ag1ii⋅⋅⋅Ag1iii 6.918(1), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1ii 8.298(1). Symmetry operators: (i) -0.5 + x, 0.5 - y, 2 - z, (ii) 0.5 - x, 1 - y, -0.5 + z, (iii) -x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 - z.

elements.content: To get a deeper insight into the framework of 1, we have performed its topological analysis using TOPOS software and the concept of the simplified underlying net. Hence, by contracting μ3-PTAO moieties to their centroids and by omitting NO3 – ligands, the structure of 1 can be considered as an underlying net (Figures c and ) composed of the 3-connected Ag1 and PTAO nodes that are topologically equivalent, giving rise to an uninodal 3-connected MOF with the point (Schläfli) symbol of (103). It means that any node participates in the formation of three 10-membered shortest circuits. This simplified net resembles the srs (SrSi2) topology according to the RCSR classification. Although MOFs of the srs topological type are well-known, those constructed from a somewhat related to PTAO building block, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt), are limited to only two examples. These include cubic [Ag(μ3-hmt)] n (PF6) n ·nH2O and [Cu3(L)3(μ3-hmt)] n {L = 1,1′-(1,4-phenylene)-bis(hexane-1,3-dione)} nets assembled from 3-connected μ3-hmt and trigonal Ag or complex Cu3(L)3 nodes, respectively.
elements.clean_text: To get a deeper insight into the framework of 1, we have performed its topological analysis using TOPOS software and the concept of the simplified underlying net. Hence, by contracting μ3-PTAO moieties to their centroids and by omitting NO3 - ligands, the structure of 1 can be considered as an underlying net (Figures c and ) composed of the 3-connected Ag1 and PTAO nodes that are topologically equivalent, giving rise to an uninodal 3-connected MOF with the point (Schläfli) symbol of (103). It means that any node participates in the formation of three 10-membered shortest circuits. This simplified net resembles the srs (SrSi2) topology according to the RCSR classification. Although MOFs of the srs topological type are well-known, those constructed from a somewhat related to PTAO building block, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt), are limited to only two examples. These include cubic [Ag(μ3-hmt)] n (PF6) n ⋅nH2O and [Cu3(L)3(μ3-hmt)] n  {L = 1,1'-(1,4-phenylene)-bis(hexane-1,3-dione)} nets assembled from 3-connected μ3-hmt and trigonal Ag or complex Cu3(L)3 nodes, respectively.

elements.content: In contrast to 1, the crystal structure of 2 (Figure ) features a more complicated 3D noninterpenetrating network owing to the presence of the two symmetry nonequivalent Ag1 and Ag2 atoms, one μ5-PTAO and one μ2-SO4 moiety, and one terminal aqua ligand (at the Ag2) per formula unit. The Ag1 atom adopts a rather distorted {AgO2N2} tetrahedral environment filled by the N11, N13ii, and O1i atoms [Ag1–N11 2.391(3), Ag1–N13ii 2.355(3), Ag1–O1i 2.652(4) Å] from three adjacent μ5-PTAO spacers and the O11 atom [Ag1–O11 2.460(4) Å] of bridging sulfate ligand (Figure a). The Ag2 atom also forms a significantly distorted {AgO3N} tetrahedral SBU with the N12 and O1iv donors [Ag2–N12 2.390(3), Ag2–O1iv 2.553(3) Å] coming from μ5-PTAO, and the O11iii and O10 atoms [Ag2–O11iii 2.399(4), Ag2–O10 2.534(4) Å] from μ2-SO4 and H2O ligands, respectively. In the construction of 2, a main role is thus played by the μ5-PTAO spacers that unprecedentedly act as tetradentate ligands and multiply assemble the adjacent {AgO2N2} and {AgO3N} SBUs into a new type of complex 3D framework (Figures b and ). It is interesting to note that owing to the presence of the phosphine oxide moiety, the 3D network of 2 significantly differs from the 2D layers generated in the reaction of silver(I) sulfate with hexamethylenetetramine as a spacer.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to 1, the crystal structure of 2 (Figure ) features a more complicated 3D noninterpenetrating network owing to the presence of the two symmetry nonequivalent Ag1 and Ag2 atoms, one μ5-PTAO and one μ2-SO4 moiety, and one terminal aqua ligand (at the Ag2) per formula unit. The Ag1 atom adopts a rather distorted {AgO2N2} tetrahedral environment filled by the N11, N13ii, and O1i atoms [Ag1-N11 2.391(3), Ag1-N13ii 2.355(3), Ag1-O1i 2.652(4) Å] from three adjacent μ5-PTAO spacers and the O11 atom [Ag1-O11 2.460(4) Å] of bridging sulfate ligand (Figure a). The Ag2 atom also forms a significantly distorted {AgO3N} tetrahedral SBU with the N12 and O1iv donors [Ag2-N12 2.390(3), Ag2-O1iv 2.553(3) Å] coming from μ5-PTAO, and the O11iii and O10 atoms [Ag2-O11iii 2.399(4), Ag2-O10 2.534(4) Å] from μ2-SO4 and H2O ligands, respectively. In the construction of 2, a main role is thus played by the μ5-PTAO spacers that unprecedentedly act as tetradentate ligands and multiply assemble the adjacent {AgO2N2} and {AgO3N} SBUs into a new type of complex 3D framework (Figures b and ). It is interesting to note that owing to the presence of the phosphine oxide moiety, the 3D network of 2 significantly differs from the 2D layers generated in the reaction of silver(I) sulfate with hexamethylenetetramine as a spacer.

elements.content: By applying the above-mentioned concept of the underlying net, we can simplify the structure of 2 by contracting μ5-PTAO and μ2-SO4 moieties to their centroids and omitting terminal H2O ligands. The resulting network (Figures c and ) is thus composed of the 3-connected Ag2, 4-connected Ag1 and 5-connected PTAO nodes as well as μ2-SO4 linkers. The topological analysis reveals a trinodal 3,4,5-connected network with the new topology defined by the point symbol of (5.6.7)(54.6.8)(54.63.83), wherein the notations (5.6.7), (54.6.8), and (54.63.83) concern the Ag2, Ag1, and PTAO nodes, respectively. To our knowledge, this type of topology has not been observed in any other coordination or H-bonded networks. In contrast to the large family of mono- and binodal MOFs, the multinodal networks are still little common, although the progress in crystal engineering resulted in the rapidly increasing number of such materials. In particular, a few 3,4,5-connected nets have emerged in recent years.
elements.clean_text: By applying the above-mentioned concept of the underlying net, we can simplify the structure of 2 by contracting μ5-PTAO and μ2-SO4 moieties to their centroids and omitting terminal H2O ligands. The resulting network (Figures c and ) is thus composed of the 3-connected Ag2, 4-connected Ag1 and 5-connected PTAO nodes as well as μ2-SO4 linkers. The topological analysis reveals a trinodal 3,4,5-connected network with the new topology defined by the point symbol of (5.6.7)(54.6.8)(54.63.83), wherein the notations (5.6.7), (54.6.8), and (54.63.83) concern the Ag2, Ag1, and PTAO nodes, respectively. To our knowledge, this type of topology has not been observed in any other coordination or H-bonded networks. In contrast to the large family of mono- and binodal MOFs, the multinodal networks are still little common, although the progress in crystal engineering resulted in the rapidly increasing number of such materials. In particular, a few 3,4,5-connected nets have emerged in recent years.

elements.content: The search for applications of MOFs across biology and medicine (so-called BioMOFs) is nowadays a rapidly developing research direction. Since silver compounds are widely used as effective antimicrobial agents, various Ag coordination polymers have also been screened recently for potential antimicrobial activity. Bearing these features in mind, we have tested compounds 1 and 2 for their in vitro antibacterial and antifungal activities against Gram-negative Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, as well as Candida albicans fungi. These studies were performed by the serial dilutions method using the Antibiotic Broth, and the obtained activities are expressed as the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC, μg mL–1) of compound that fully inhibits microbial growth. Hence, both 1 and 2 exhibit significant antibacterial and antifungal activity showing a comparable behavior, with stronger activities against E. coli and P. aeruginosa strains and the MIC values in the 6–7 μg mL–1 range, whereas S. aureus and C. albicans are more resistant resulting in the MIC values of 20–30 μg mL–1. In contrast, PTAO shows very low efficiency with the MIC values in the 1100–2200 μg mL–1 range (). In general, the levels of activity exhibited by 1 and 2 are noticeably higher in comparison with those of some other silver(I) coordination compounds.
elements.clean_text: The search for applications of MOFs across biology and medicine (so-called BioMOFs) is nowadays a rapidly developing research direction. Since silver compounds are widely used as effective antimicrobial agents, various Ag coordination polymers have also been screened recently for potential antimicrobial activity. Bearing these features in mind, we have tested compounds 1 and 2 for their in vitro antibacterial and antifungal activities against Gram-negative Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, as well as Candida albicans fungi. These studies were performed by the serial dilutions method using the Antibiotic Broth, and the obtained activities are expressed as the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC, μg mL-1) of compound that fully inhibits microbial growth. Hence, both 1 and 2 exhibit significant antibacterial and antifungal activity showing a comparable behavior, with stronger activities against E. coli and P. aeruginosa strains and the MIC values in the 6-7 μg mL-1 range, whereas S. aureus and C. albicans are more resistant resulting in the MIC values of 20-30 μg mL-1. In contrast, PTAO shows very low efficiency with the MIC values in the 1100-2200 μg mL-1 range (). In general, the levels of activity exhibited by 1 and 2 are noticeably higher in comparison with those of some other silver(I) coordination compounds.

elements.content: In summary, the present study has opened up the use of PTAO as a new and versatile diamondoid building block in the design of MOFs, resulting in the self-assembly generation of the two novel 3D silver–organic networks 1 and 2, their structures featuring the unprecedented N2O- or N3O-coordination modes of PTAO. The work also shows how a slight modification of the starting silver(I) salt has a marked effect on the topology of the resulting PTAO driven networks. In the case of using AgNO3, a uninodal 3-connected helical net with the srs topology is obtained, while the use of Ag2SO4 leads to a rare trinodal 3,4,5-connected net with a hitherto undocumented topology. Besides, both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit high antibacterial and antifungal activities, and represent the first examples of 3D MOFs derived from PTAO or any cage-like PTA derivative. The research toward further exploration of PTAO as a convenient multidentate N,O-building block in the design of new MOFs is currently in progress.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the present study has opened up the use of PTAO as a new and versatile diamondoid building block in the design of MOFs, resulting in the self-assembly generation of the two novel 3D silver-organic networks 1 and 2, their structures featuring the unprecedented N2O- or N3O-coordination modes of PTAO. The work also shows how a slight modification of the starting silver(I) salt has a marked effect on the topology of the resulting PTAO driven networks. In the case of using AgNO3, a uninodal 3-connected helical net with the srs topology is obtained, while the use of Ag2SO4 leads to a rare trinodal 3,4,5-connected net with a hitherto undocumented topology. Besides, both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit high antibacterial and antifungal activities, and represent the first examples of 3D MOFs derived from PTAO or any cage-like PTA derivative. The research toward further exploration of PTAO as a convenient multidentate N,O-building block in the design of new MOFs is currently in progress.

elements.content: Materials and methods, refinement details of X-ray analyses, procedure and results (Table S1) for antibacterial and antifungal activity studies, additional structural representations (Figures S1–S4), and crystallographic files in CIF format for 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Materials and methods, refinement details of X-ray analyses, procedure and results (Table S1) for antibacterial and antifungal activity studies, additional structural representations (Figures S1-S4), and crystallographic files in CIF format for 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content:
For limited examples of PTAO complexes, see:

Synthesis and analytical data: Compound 1: To a MeOH (5 mL) solution of silver nitrate (0.2 mmol, 34 mg) was added PTAO (0.2 mmol, 35 mg) dissolved in MeOH/CH2Cl2 (10 mL/2.5 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred at room temperature (r.t., 20 °C) for 30 min to produce a white suspension, which was subjected to a dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M solution of NH4OH (ca. 0.15 mL, until pH ≈ 8.5) and then filtered off. The filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at r.t. Colorless crystals (including those of X-ray quality) were formed in 1–2 weeks, then collected and dried in air to give 1 in ∼50% yield, based on AgNO3. C6H12AgN4O4P (343.0): calcd. C 21.01, N 16.33, H 3.53; found: C 21.10, N 16.04, H 3.42. S 25 °C (in H2O) ≈ 2.0 mg mL–1. IR (KBr): 2971 (w) νas(CH), 2932 (w) νs(CH), 1440 (w), 1384 (vs br.), 1283 (s), 1234 (m), 1165 s ν(PO), 1095 (w), 1003 (s), 973 (s), 903 (s), 825 (w), 807 (s), 785 (m), 752 (w), 615 (w), 575 (m), 543 (w), 449 (m) and 416 (w) cm–1. 1H NMR (500.1 MHz, D2O, Me4Si): δ 4.60 and 4.03 (2d, 6H, J AB = 13.4 Hz, NCH A H BN), 4.03 (d, 6H, 3 J P-H = 10.3 Hz, PCH 2N). 31P{1H} NMR (202.5 MHz, D2O, 85% H3PO4): δ −2.89 (s). ESI-MS(±) (H2O), selected fragments with relative abundance >10%: MS(+), m/z: 454 (50%) [Ag(PTA=O)2]+, 319 (100%) [Ag(PTAO)(H2O)2]+, 281 (20%) [Ag(PTAO)]+, 174 (15%) [PTAO + H]+; MS(−), m/z: 232 (100%) [Ag(NO3)2]−. Compound 2: To a MeCN (5 mL) solution of silver sulfate (0.1 mmol, 31 mg) was added PTAO (0.2 mmol, 35 mg) dissolved in MeCN/H2O (5 mL/1 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred at r.t. (20 °C) for 30 min, followed by filtration. The filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at r.t, furnishing colorless crystals (including those of X-ray quality) in 1–2 weeks. These were collected and dried in air to give 2 in ∼50% yield, based on Ag2SO4. C6H14Ag2N3O6PS (503.0): calcd. C 14.33, N 8.35, H 2.81; found: C 14.53, N 8.27, H 2.76. S 25 °C (in H2O) ≈ 5.0 mg mL–1. IR (KBr): 3320 (m br.) ν(H2O), 2930 (w) νas(CH), 2871 (w) νs(CH), 1635 (m br.) δ(H2O), 1439 (m), 1407 (m), 1283 (s), 1234 (m), 1144 (sh.) + 1138 (vs br.) ν(PO) + ν(SO4), 1004 (m), 972 (s), 943 (m), 903 (s), 806 (m), 676 (m br.), 619 (s), 577 (m), 542 (w) and 450 (m) cm–1. 1H NMR (500.1 MHz, D2O, Me4Si): δ 4.41 and 4.27 (2d, 6H, J AB = 14.0 Hz, NCH A H BN), 4.04 (d, 6H, 3 J P-H = 10.3 Hz, PCH 2N). 31P{1H} NMR (202.5 MHz, D2O, 85% H3PO4): δ −3.00 (s). ESI-MS(±) (H2O), selected fragments with relative abundance >10%: MS(+), m/z: 454 (30%) [Ag(PTAO)2]+, 319 (100%) [Ag(PTAO)(H2O)2]+, 281 (10%) [Ag(PTAO)]+, 174 (20%) [PTAO + H]+; MS(−), m/z: 204 (30%) [Ag(SO4)]−, 97 (100%) [HSO4]−.

elements.content: Crystal data: 1: C6H12AgN4O4P, M = 343.04, λ = 0.71073 Å (Mo-Kα), T = 150(2) K, orthorhombic, space group P212121, a = 7.7286(4), b = 10.0328(6), c = 13.4998(8) Å, V = 1046.77(10) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.177 g/cm3, F 000 = 680, μ = 2.08 mm–1, 5720 reflections collected, 2021 unique, I > 2σ(I) (R int = 0.0224), R 1 = 0.0165, wR 2 = 0.0480, Flack parameter 0.02(2). 2: C6H14Ag2N3O6PS, M = 502.97, λ = 0.71073 Å (Mo-Kα), T = 296(2) K, orthorhombic, space group Pna21, a = 16.6597(7), b = 10.3551(4), c = 6.9008(3) Å, V = 1190.48(9) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.806 g/cm3, F 000 = 976, μ = 3.63 mm–1, 7412 reflections collected, 2143 unique, I > 2σ(I) (R int = 0.0225), R 1 = 0.0188, wR 2 = 0.0465, Flack parameter −0.02(3).

cln_elements.content:
The reaction of silver(I) nitrate with PTAO as the main ligand and spacer, in equimolar amounts at 20 °C in MeOH/CH2Cl2 medium, followed by the alkalization with NH4OH, leads to the self-assembly formation of the polymer 1, in which PTAO acts as a μ3-spacer (Scheme ). However, a resembling synthetic procedure with silver(I) sulfate as the metal source and in MeCN/H2O medium (different solvent composition was used to facilitate crystallization) results in the generation of the distinct and more complex polymer 2, wherein the coordination network is driven by neutral μ5-PTAO spacers and μ2-SO4 linkers. These MOFs have been isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on Ag salt). As expected for PTA derivatives, compounds 1 and 2 are moderately soluble in water, showing the S 25°C values of 2.0 and 5.0 mg mL–1, respectively. Their molecular structures have been established by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, and supported by elemental analysis, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS)(±), IR and NMR spectroscopies.

Crystal data: 1: C6H12AgN4O4P, M = 343.04, λ = 0.71073 Å (Mo-Kα), T = 150(2) K, orthorhombic, space group P212121, a = 7.7286(4), b = 10.0328(6), c = 13.4998(8) Å, V = 1046.77(10) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.177 g/cm3, F 000 = 680, μ = 2.08 mm–1, 5720 reflections collected, 2021 unique, I > 2σ(I) (R int = 0.0224), R 1 = 0.0165, wR 2 = 0.0480, Flack parameter 0.02(2). 2: C6H14Ag2N3O6PS, M = 502.97, λ = 0.71073 Å (Mo-Kα), T = 296(2) K, orthorhombic, space group Pna21, a = 16.6597(7), b = 10.3551(4), c = 6.9008(3) Å, V = 1190.48(9) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.806 g/cm3, F 000 = 976, μ = 3.63 mm–1, 7412 reflections collected, 2143 unique, I > 2σ(I) (R int = 0.0225), R 1 = 0.0188, wR 2 = 0.0465, Flack parameter −0.02(3).

However, a resembling synthetic procedure with silver(I) sulfate as the metal source and in MeCN/H2O medium (different solvent composition was used to facilitate crystallization) results in the generation of the distinct and more complex polymer 2, wherein the coordination network is driven by neutral μ5-PTAO spacers and μ2-SO4 linkers. These MOFs have been isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on Ag salt). As expected for PTA derivatives, compounds 1 and 2 are moderately soluble in water, showing the S 25°C values of 2.0 and 5.0 mg mL-1, respectively. cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-00571y_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulae of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> <xref rid="sch2-fn1"></xref>

Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulae of 1 and 2       a Numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) N-coordination or (2,3) O-coordination of PTAO, and (4) O-coordination of sulfate ligand (in 2). The scheme also shows how a slight modification of silver(I) salt leads to structurally distinct compounds.

cln_elements.content: Structural fragments of 1 showing: (a) ellipsoid plot with partial labeling scheme, (b) helical 3D framework, and (c) topological representation of the simplified underlying 3-connected net with the point symbol of (103). Further details: (a) 50% probability ellipsoids, H atoms are omitted for clarity; (b) rotated view along the a axis, H atoms and nitrate ligands are omitted for clarity, color codes: Ag balls (magenta), N (blue), P (orange), O (red), C (cyan); (c) rotated view along the c axis, topologically equivalent 3-connected Ag1 nodes and centroids of PTAO nodes are shown as magenta and cyan sticks, respectively. Selected distances (Å): Ag1–N11 2.341(2), Ag1–N13i 2.309(2), Ag1–O1 2.414(2), Ag1–O11 2.562(3), Ag1–O12 2.739(2), P1–O1 1.490(2), Ag1···Ag1iii 5.939(1), Ag1ii···Ag1iii 6.918(1), Ag1···Ag1ii 8.298(1). Symmetry operators: (i) −0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, 2 – z, (ii) 0.5 – x, 1 – y, −0.5 + z, (iii) –x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 – z.

Further details: (a) 50% probability ellipsoids, H atoms (apart from those of H2O ligand) are omitted for clarity; (b) rotated view along the c axis, H atoms and H2O ligands are omitted for clarity, color codes: Ag balls (magenta), N (blue), P (orange), O (red), C (cyan), SO4 2– (yellow); (c) rotated view along the c axis, color codes: 3-connected Ag2 nodes (pale pink), 4-connected Ag1 nodes (magenta), centroids of 5-connected PTAO nodes (cyan) and centroids of μ2-SO4 2– linkers (yellow). Selected distances (Å): Ag1–N11 2.391(3), Ag1–N13ii 2.355(3), Ag1–O1i 2.652(4), Ag1–O11 2.460(4), Ag2–N12 2.390(3), Ag2–O1iv 2.553(3), Ag2–O10 2.534(4), Ag2–O11iii 2.399(4), P1–O1 1.495(3), Ag1···Ag2v 3.936(1), Ag1vi···Ag2vii 4.715(1), Ag1viii···Ag2 5.912(1), Ag1···Ag1viii 6.328(1), Ag2···Ag2vii 6.322(1), Ag1···Ag2 6.540(1), Ag1···Ag1vi 6.900(1). Symmetry operators: (i) x, y, −1 + z, (ii) −0.5 – x, 0.5 + y, −0.5 + z; (iii) 0.5 + x, 1.5 – y, z, (iv) –x, 2 – y, −0.5 + z, (v) −0.5 + x, 1.5 + y, z, (vi) x, y, 1 + z, (vii) –x, 2 – y, 0.5 + z, (viii) −0.5 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 + z.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Structural fragments of 2 showing: (a) ellipsoid plot with partial labeling scheme, (b) complex 3D framework, and (c) unprecedented topology of the simplified underlying 3,4,5-connected net with the point symbol of (5.6.7)(54.6.8)(54.63.83). Further details: (a) 50% probability ellipsoids, H atoms (apart from those of H2O ligand) are omitted for clarity; (b) rotated view along the c axis, H atoms and H2O ligands are omitted for clarity, color codes: Ag balls (magenta), N (blue), P (orange), O (red), C (cyan), SO4 2- (yellow); (c) rotated view along the c axis, color codes: 3-connected Ag2 nodes (pale pink), 4-connected Ag1 nodes (magenta), centroids of 5-connected PTAO nodes (cyan) and centroids of μ2-SO4 2- linkers (yellow). Selected distances (Å): Ag1-N11 2.391(3), Ag1-N13ii 2.355(3), Ag1-O1i 2.652(4), Ag1-O11 2.460(4), Ag2-N12 2.390(3), Ag2-O1iv 2.553(3), Ag2-O10 2.534(4), Ag2-O11iii 2.399(4), P1-O1 1.495(3), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag2v 3.936(1), Ag1vi⋅⋅⋅Ag2vii 4.715(1), Ag1viii⋅⋅⋅Ag2 5.912(1), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1viii 6.328(1), Ag2⋅⋅⋅Ag2vii 6.322(1), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag2 6.540(1), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1vi 6.900(1). Symmetry operators: (i) x, y, -1 + z, (ii) -0.5 - x, 0.5 + y, -0.5 + z; (iii) 0.5 + x, 1.5 - y, z, (iv) -x, 2 - y, -0.5 + z, (v) -0.5 + x, 1.5 + y, z, (vi) x, y, 1 + z, (vii) -x, 2 - y, 0.5 + z, (viii) -0.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 + z.

metadata.title: 1,3,5-Triaza-7-phosphaadamantane-7-oxide (PTAO): New Diamondoid Building Block for Design of Three-Dimensional Metal–Organic Frameworks
author_list:
Guedes da Silva
M. Fátima C.
